summary:
Tim, bound and gagged, listening to a group of people haggle over his fate, is hard-pressed to think of how this situation can get worse.

Then Hood walks in.

Jason's POV of the first scene. [Batcellanea ch208.]
text:
Tim can admit he’s in trouble, and this is probably exactly why Bruce insisted he not patrol solo while Bruce and Alfred were overseas. Dick—Dick hasn’t been in much contact since Tim was attacked at the Tower, and Tim can’t even blame him. Tim is an embarrassment to the Robin mantle, and while he’s grateful Bruce didn’t fire him, Dick certainly wouldn’t want to stick around.

 

Trying to prove he could be a worthy Robin has ended up with him bound and gagged, kneeling on the floor, listening to two men argue over the best way to sell him and his secret identity. He can’t slip the handcuffs, not with a gun held to his head. Apparently, they’ve dealt with the Bats before and are aware of their ability to slip out of almost anything. And—Tim wiggles his fingers, trying to keep feeling in them—he’s not sure he’d be able to slip handcuffs this tight anyways. If his hands were free, he’d still have to pick the chains cuffing him to the floor after.

 

An auction seems to be their best idea, and Tim wonders if that will buy enough time for anyone to get to the Cave and see his emergency alert.

 

When a door slams open, and Hood strides in like he owns the warehouse, Tim goes deathly still. Maybe Hood won’t notice—

 

“I hear you have a bird for sale.”

 

Or maybe Hood is here specifically for him.

 

Tim swallows, and flexes his fingers, real fear running through him. Being sold in an auction in the future was nebulous, a fuzzy maybe. He had plans to slip away during transit, plans to bribe them himself if money was all they wanted.

 

Hood might just shoot him right here, money be damned.

 

“He’s not for sale yet,” argues one of the men, and the rest shift away from him. Tim doesn’t blame them; arguing with Hood is asking to be shot.

 

Just like wearing Hood’s old colors.

 

“Just name your price,” says the mechanized voice that Tim can never forget.

 

He tries to take a deep breath through his nose, ignoring the gag. He tries to pretend this isn’t happening. Maybe they’ll refuse to sell him to Hood, wanting to drive the price up at the auction, and maybe—

 

“What do you even want him for? If you’re just gonna shoot ‘im, we wanna sell him to someone else. The little brat—” someone kicks him and Tim grunts, “—needs to pay for fuckin’ with us for so long.” The rest of the men shift even further away from the speaker, but still look to Hood for an answer. 

 

Tim can probably handle more pain. He survived the Tower, and Hood had every opportunity to kill him, but he didn’t, so maybe he doesn’t just want to kill Tim. Tim handle pain, even if takes days before— 

 

“He’s good for more than just shooting,” Hood says, with an edge to his voice that makes Tim blood run cold. The men standing around laugh, and Tim shudders.

 

No. No, Hood wouldn’t do that. He only kills more gang members than rapists because gang members keep getting in his way. He hunts down the rapists personally. 

 

But then again, Hood has never hurt a child or an innocent, and most people would consider a fifteen year old wearing Robin’s colors to qualify. So, Tim has always been the exception.

 

“You want us to believe you want Robin for that?” asks the man with a death wish, who hasn’t seemed to notice how everyone keeps edging away from him. It’s possible they’re not unaware that they’re trafficking a child, and that Hood might just be letting them wrap the noose around their own necks. 

 

Tim doesn’t think Hood is doing that. Hood could have shot them all as soon as he walked into the building, or even before. Hood is here for him, and apparently he’s not going to be shy about what he wants.

 

Even if Hood lets him go, everyone—everyone will know, and they’ll always remind him of it.

 

Horror rushes through him, and he closes his eyes, telling himself it’s not to keep the tears back. He just needs to clear his head. Hood isn’t going to do this. This is some sort of a ruse. He wants intel from these men. But Tim’s heart is racing, and his throat is tight, and he doesn’t know what to believe.

 

He has vivid memories of Hood hurting him, again and again, in the Tower. They don’t inspire confidence in Hood’s goodwill, and Tim can feel small shivers running through his body.

 

Hood and the men are still talking, but Tim is carefully tuning it out. Hood will or won’t buy him. His knees hurt from being on the floor so long, and his hands twist uselessly in the handcuffs; he’s helpless. It doesn’t matter what they say.

 

All of a sudden, someone is ripping the gag out of his mouth, harsh and painful, and Tim looks up to see Hood right in front of him.

 

“What do you say, Robin? You going to come with me?”

 

“Hood—” Tim says, and stops. 

 

Hood’s body stays relaxed. “Here’s what's going to happen, Robin. These nice men here are going to unchain your legs, and you’re going to stand up and come with me, and not make any trouble.”

 

Tim stares at him. Are you delusional?

 

“Why would I do that?” he asks, voice hoarse.

 

“I don’t think you want to piss me off any more. I can be gentle, if you give me the right incentive.” The men around them laugh, again, and Tim swallows hard.

 

Moment of truth. Be daring, be brave, be Robin.

 

“Everyone knows you don’t like rapists, Hood. Not sure you’re going to make good on that threat.” It might be more convincing if his voice wasn’t trembling.

 

Hood crouches down, still relaxed, and Tim manages not to flinch away. He looks right at Tim, and Tim stares back at that expressionless helmet, not daring to breathe.

 

Between one blink and the next, Hood pulls out a gun and cracks it across his face. Before Tim can process what just happened, before the pain has even registered, Hood grabs his head and shoves the gun in his mouth.

 

The metal is cold, and his teeth click against the barrel. There’s a bitter taste and a little voice says gunpowder, but most of his brain is reeling with the fact that there is a gun in his mouth.

 

Hood pistol-whipped him and put a gun in his mouth.

 

Tim looks up at him, shocked and terrified, pain radiating from his cheek, as Hood calmly says, “Sweetheart, don’t fucking push me.”

 

Tim should fight back. That’s what Robin would do, and he wants to be Robin, but he keeps showing over and over again that he isn’t Robin. And there’s a gun is his mouth, and he knows what else Hood wants to put in his mouth and—

 

He swallows around the gun, all his carefully constructed bravado bleeding out of him.

 

Hood says, “Good,” with such blatant satisfaction is his voice that Tim knows he can’t ever be Robin again. Not after this. Not after— 

 

The men are laughing again, and Hood says, “A bitch needs to know his place,” and Tim shudders as Hood draws the gun back out of his mouth. “You know your place, sweetheart?”

 

Looking at the ground, trying to hide the tears springing up in his eyes, he nods. He doesn’t trust his voice not to crack, not to start begging, and he knows he’s likely to beg before it’s over, but maybe he can hold out until they’re alone, at least.

 

There’s a click, and the cuffs fall off his legs. This would—this would be the chance to try to run, to try to kick, to do something, but there’s an echo of metal in his mouth, he’s trying not to cry, and he’s almost frozen with terror. He can’t even look up.

 

Hood rises to his feet and says, “Get up,” and Tim does so without hesitation, fear of disobeying overwhelming him. It’s already going to be awful and if—would Hood really make it worse? Tim wants—it would be better—Hood said he would be gentle, if Tim—so he will. Tim will—he swallows, painful with a tight throat. Tim will know his place. 

 

Tim doesn’t look up, even as one of the men says, “You need a leash for that bitch, Hood? It might still give you trouble.”

 

A gloved hand grabs his chin, and a thumb digs into the tender bruise forming on his cheek. He whimpers, but makes himself hold still and not resist as Hood forces his head up. Tim looks at Hood through blurred vision, lips trembling, cheek aching, and Hood lets his head fall back down with a bark of laughter.

 

“Not this one. Not as much fire as you might expect, for one of them.” 

 

When Hood takes a step forward, Tim follows him, trembling all over. Maybe—maybe Hood will leave him alive when he’s done, dump him on the streets, or—or maybe Tim will survive long enough for his rescue beacon to be noticed and tracked. Maybe there’ll be a miracle, and Dick will stop by the Cave.

 

Maybe all they’ll find at the end of that beacon is a body.

 

 

Tim follows Jason all the way out of the warehouse to his motorcycle. The kid can’t hang on with his hands cuffed behind his back, and Jason isn’t sure who’s still watching, so he draws his gun before he uncuffs him. Tim is unsettlingly still; Jason wonders if they drugged him, because the kid didn’t roll over half this easy in the Tower.

 

But he gets on the motorcycle, still wordless, and Jason can take him back to a safehouse and smuggle him back to the Bats. Give him another week, and he can take down that entire trafficking ring, and anyone who remembers Hood buying Robin will be a distant memory.

 

Tim is rigid behind him on the motorcycle. He didn’t protest getting on, didn’t even protest when Jason ordered him to wrap his arms around Jason, but his entire body is stiff.

 

He hoped the kid was just playing along, would know Hood wouldn’t buy a person, wouldn’t rape anyone, no matter how fucking much he hated them. But maybe the pistol-whip and shoving the gun in his mouth was over-selling it.

 

Jason remembers what it looked like, and has to fight not to lose his dinner right then and there.  The safety was on, he reminds himself, again and again, because Jason double-checked before he did it—it was the fastest way he could think of to get the traffickers to back off without hurting the kid too much.

 

Jason doesn’t know if he made the right choice.  They—there are more children, and he hasn’t been able to find all of them, and he could’ve killed every single person in that warehouse, but he would’ve never found the rest of the kids.  This is Robin, he would understand—

 

The kid starts trembling, and Jason changes his plan on the fly.  He doesn’t know where Batman is, but he’s getting Tim back to the Cave.  He can do a few reroutes to throw off any pursuers, and they won’t be able to get into the tunnels anyway.  Tim deserves to go back somewhere safe.

 

He still doesn’t fight.  Jason takes him through Gotham, and across the bridge into Bristol, and not a peep.  Not a twitch.  Not even trying to jump off and escape—Jason is going fast, but not that fast.

 

Jason tries to tell himself that it’s because Tim understands that it was a front.  That if he truly thought Jason was taking him somewhere to—to rape him, he would fight back.  That the trembling kid clutching Jason is doing so because he believes Jason will protect him, not because he thinks Jason is going to hurt him worse if he tries to run.

 

The kid’s breathing turns shallow and fast when they hit the turn-off to the Cave.  Jason thinks he hears him whimper “no,” but he’s focused on entering in the passcode—they still haven’t kicked him out of their system—and speeding through the Cave.  The parking is where it’s always been, and Jason lets out a slow breath when he turns the engine off.

 

The Cave is dark.  No Alfred, no Bruce.  “Get off,” Jason nudges to the kid still clinging to him, and winces when the distorter makes it harsher than he intended.

 

Tim shakily dismounts, stumbling forward on legs like a fawn’s.  He’s shaking all over, and Jason unfreezes enough to pull off his helmet.  “Tim,” he says slowly, careful to keep his movements steady and his hands away from his guns.

 

Tim turns jerkily.  He sways, like he wants to get away from Jason, but can’t move his feet.  Jason gives him the widest berth possible as he heads deeper into the Cave.  He checks the Batcomputer, sees that the kid did manage to get out an alert.  Bruce is on his way back already.  Nightwing is in the middle of a mission and is frantically demanding updates; he looks to be ten seconds away from torpedoing it in favor of rushing back to Gotham.

 

Jason cancels the alert and responds with an all clear.  Pauses.  Signs his name to it—not like that’ll make them panic any less, but he needs Bruce and Dick to come home as soon as possible.

 

When he turns around, he sees that the kid has followed him.  Catalogues the pallor of his skin.  Watches the kid gracefully fold to his knees.

 

Jason doesn’t move a muscle.

 

“Please,” Tim whispers. “Please not here.”

 

It’s a struggle not to bend over and throw up right where he is.

 

“Tim,” Jason says slowly. “I’m not going to hurt you.  I’m not going to touch you.”

 

The kid is shaking, violent tremors wracking his frame, and he doesn’t respond.  Fuck.  He’s still too pale, his breathing on the edge of hyperventilation.

 

Jason heads for the medbay—the kid struggles to his feet to follow him, and Jason wants to shout ‘no’ but is well aware of what that sounds like.

 

Tim stills when they draw closer to the medbay.  The tremors ease, replaced with floaty, raspy breaths, and he climbs on a bed before Jason can say anything.

 

Jason does not want to imagine what’s running through the kid’s head right now.  Unfortunately, his mind is not that considerate.

 

Jason ignores him to rifle through the cupboard containing the extra blankets, and draws out the thickest, most vibrantly colored ones he can get.  One is a Green Lantern patterned blanket, which explains why it was at the very bottom.

 

Keeping his movements slow and careful—he said he wasn’t going to touch the kid, and he isn’t going to break that—Jason tugs the first blanket around Tim’s shoulders.  He can’t see the kid’s eyes behind the domino mask, but the confusion is palpable as Jason finishes wrapping the first blanket and gets the next.  He’s created a nice little Tim burrito by the time he’s done, an owlish head poking out from the blankets.

 

Jason steps back.  And another.  And another, keeping his hands in easy view.  He chooses the cot furthest from the one Tim is on, and hops up to sit on it cross-legged, tearing off his mask while he’s at it.  He considers removing his armor, but that would probably give the kid the wrong idea, so he settles for unbuckling his holsters and throwing them into the corner.  No guns.

 

Tim is watching him, mask tracking his movements, breaths slow and shaky.

 

“I’m not going to hurt you,” Jason repeats, “I’m not going to touch you.”  I’ll kill anyone who fucking tries.  “Everything I said in that warehouse was a lie.”  Sweetheart, don’t fucking push me.  “I’ve been tracking the trafficking ring for a week—they have more kids stashed somewhere, and the next drop is tomorrow.  I need them alive until I can find the kids.  I’m sorry for hurting you.  I’m sorry for—” snapping a gun across your face and shoving it in your mouth and pretending like I was the monster you clearly think I am.  “I’m sorry,” Jason finishes, because he’s sorry for so many things he doesn’t know where to start.

 

Please stop looking at me like that.

 

He keeps his hands on his knees.  He wants to leave, but he can’t leave the kid alone.  He wishes Bruce could get here faster.

 

Seconds tick by, and it’s nearly a full minute before the kid speaks.

 

“You hate me.”  Matter-of-fact.  No trembling, no wavering, nothing but a blank, empty tone.

 

Jason swallows down the ‘I would never do that to anyone, even if I hated them’ and goes for, “I don’t.”

 

“You do,” the kid’s voice is still expressionless.  Jason really hopes he hasn’t started dissociating.  “You said so.  When you broke into the Tower.”

 

Jason winces.  Not exactly his proudest memory.  He chooses his words carefully, aware that what he needs to say and what the kid needs to hear right now are not the same thing.  “I don’t hate you,” Jason says quietly, “And I’m sorry that I attacked you.”  He has so much else to say, so much about Bruce and his jealousy and taking out his rage on a convenient target, but that explanation isn’t for a kid who’s climbed past terror and gone straight to surrender.

 

Tim takes a deep breath and shudders through it.  “Hood’s not a rapist,” he says, quietly enough that he’s mostly saying it to himself.  Jason can feel his stomach clench.  On the next breath, Tim relaxes more into his little blanket mound, slumping until the edge of the blankets comes up to his nose.

 

He said a similar thing back in that warehouse.  Before Jason shoved a gun in his mouth and insinuated that Tim was the exception.

 

Jason stays where he is, stomach roiling, and breathes out slowly.

 

 

The blankets are warm.  It’s nice.  It’s nice enough to draw Tim out of the floating haze he sank into when he saw the beds, especially since Hood is sitting far away from him.

 

The Green Lantern blanket is on top, an eye-catching shade of neon green.  It’s buried at the bottom of the cupboard, so Hood would’ve had to go searching for it.  Tim asked Dick about it once, teasing at Bruce’s infamous dislike of Hal, but Dick’s answering smile had been slightly strained.

 

“It was Jason’s favorite blanket.  Not—not the one he liked to use, but the one he loved wrapping Bruce in whenever he was injured enough to stay in the medbay.”

 

And now Tim is bundled up in it.  Staring at Hood.  Staring at Jason—vivid green eyes are tracking his movements, but the gaze isn’t as...predatory as Tim remembers.

 

Tim swallows.  He can still taste gunpowder.  But Jason threw the guns in the corner—close by, Jason just has to get off the bed and walk six steps, except Jason isn’t getting off the bed.

 

“I need them alive until I can find the kids.”

 

It makes sense.  It makes more sense than Hood suddenly abandoning all his ideals and choosing to do business with child traffickers.  It makes sense, and some part of Tim uncurled in relief when Jason explained.

 

He still can’t stop shivering.  Because—because Jason isn’t going to hurt him.  Jason—Jason said it, multiple times, and Tim can’t—his helmet is off, his mask is off, and Tim can’t help but believe the Robin he followed for so many years.  Because Jason isn’t going to hurt him, but it doesn’t even matter anymore.

 

Tim won’t be Robin for much longer.

 

The thought is acutely painful, and some of it must show on his face because Jason frowns.  “What’s wrong?” he asks, his voice still quiet, nowhere near the harsh growl or vicious snarl or mocking condescension.

 

Tim shakes his head.

 

“Are—are you hurt?” Jason asks, “Do you need something?  Bruce will be here in half an hour, I think—”

 

“What?” Tim croaks out.  He saw Jason cancel the alert and give them an all-clear.  Why would Bruce come back?

 

Jason looks startled.  “He’s on his way back?  Judging by the speed he’s going, he should be back in a half-hour,” Jason says slowly, still looking confused.

 

Tim goes still.  Why would Bruce come back, unless it’s to strip Robin away from him immediately?  He can feel his whole face begin to prickle again, and he draws his knees up under the blankets and hunches down.

 

He—he knows he’s not good enough to be Robin.  Jason made that very clear in Titans Tower, and Bruce’s smothering and Dick’s distance afterwards just hammered in the lesson.  And now he got captured and Jason had to rescue him and Tim didn’t even realize that the older boy was putting on a facade for the traffickers.  He’s failed at being Robin many times over, and he knows he doesn’t deserve to keep the suit—Jason’s back, Bruce has his son back, Tim’s real purpose has ended—but the prospect of losing it still hurts.

 

Tim can’t quite strangle the sob, and Jason’s voice echoes after it, “Tim?  Are you okay?”

 

No, he’s not, and Tim can’t even blame someone else for it, he’s weak and pathetic and—and—

 

“Tim?” Jason really sounds worried now.  Because Tim can’t even accept his fate, he has to cry—in front of Jason—and make him concerned.

 

“S—sorry,” Tim forces out, not looking at the older boy, “I just—I know Bruce will t—take away R—Robin, I’m just—I don’t—I know I won’t—”

 

“What?” Jason cuts him off, “Why do you think Bruce is going to take away Robin?”

 

“B—because I messed up,” Tim’s voice cracks, “B—because I w—wasn’t supposed to g—go out, and then I got c—captured, and then—” he chokes on the inhale and suppresses the sob clawing at his throat. “And now he’s—he’s coming here and—and it’s a—all my f—fault.”

 

“It’s not your fault,” Jason says, but Tim can tell it’s a rote answer.

 

“H—he won’t t—trust me and I’m—I’m not good enough and I f—failed and got c—caught—” and all of a sudden, Tim realizes who he’s speaking to.

 

He peers out from the edge of his blankets.  Jason’s expression is blank.  “Kid,” he says, a trace of wryness to the otherwise weary tone, “You haven’t died yet, which is more than I could manage.”

 

“I didn’t mean—”

 

Jason holds up a hand, and Tim falls silent.

 

“You’re clever.  You see patterns that others don’t.  You’re pretty fucking dangerous with that staff in your hands.  If Bruce fires you, he’s making a mistake.”  Jason’s tone is nothing but sincere, and Tim feels fresh tears prickling at his eyes.

 

“T—thank you.”  This is not how Tim saw this night going, with Tim wrapped up in a Green Lantern blanket as his predecessor tries to reassure him.

 

Jason nods solemnly, like he understands.  And—and maybe he does, because he was where Tim was, except Jason never got rescued.

 

Jason’s eyes sharpen as another shiver wracks through Tim.  “Do you want some tea?” he asks quietly, “I can—I can make some, if you’d like.”

 

Tim considers the offer.  It would be nice to have something warm.  And if Jason doesn’t—doesn’t put the helmet back on, or the guns, then Tim thinks he can—can remember that Jason wasn’t trying to hurt him.

 

It still hurt, as his throbbing cheek can attest, but Tim understands.  Jason is trying to save a whole bunch of kids.

 

“Okay,” Tim acquiesces.

 

“Great,” Jason hops off the bed, and Tim stays perfectly still as Jason heads for the door.  “I’ll head up to the Manor,” Jason says slowly. “You can come up when you’re ready.”  Tim blinks, and watches Jason head for the stairs.  His guns are still in the corner.  Jason goes up the stairs without looking back, and Tim slowly, slowly uncurls.

 

His hands are stiff and his mask is digging into his cheekbone and he feels tired and sore and achy.  He can’t manage a shower, tension prickles down his spine at the thought, and Tim eventually just changes into a long-sleeved shirt and sweatpants.  And grabs a Superboy hoodie to throw over it, surrounding himself in warmth.

 

When he gets to the kitchen, he sees that Jason has stashed his armor and gear somewhere, because he’s barefoot, still in the cargo pants, but wearing a thin black shirt with the sleeves rolled up to his elbow, no leather jacket.  Jason glances up at him as he enters, but doesn’t say anything, squinting intently at the cup of sugar he’s measuring.  Ingredients litter the kitchen counter and, after a brief hesitation, Tim chooses a stool on the counter opposite Jason.

 

The kettle is on the stove, and two mugs are next to it.

 

“What are you making?” Tim asks softly.  He can see flour and cinnamon and eggs and vanilla extract.

 

Jason takes the hand mixer and checks to make sure it’s plugged in before he turns it on.  “Snickerdoodles,” Jason says, mixing together what looks like butter and sugar.

 

Tim watches him—he’s never seen this side of Jason and with the helmet off, he looks like the nineteen-year-old he is, instead of the drug lord that haunts Tim’s nightmares.  He looks like a kid, flour-dusted hands passing Tim a mug of steaming honey-lemon tea before returning to the dough.

 

Tim curls his hands around the mug and feels it warm him, inside and out.

 

He looks like—almost like—like the brother that Tim never got.

 

The honey-lemon taste replaces the gunpowder, and watching Jason knead the sticky dough with the scent of cinnamon rising in the air, he can almost forget the way that hand curled around a gun.

 

Jason curses when he realizes he forgot to preheat the oven, and the annoyed grumbling doesn’t sound angry.  Tim has only ever gotten two emotions out of Hood—anger or glee—and seeing the spectrum is...soothing.

 

“I don’t hate you.”

 

And Tim can almost believe it.

 

Tim takes another sip of tea and almost chokes on it when Batman appears in the doorway like a wraith—Tim didn’t hear a thing, he just blinked, and there he was.

 

Jason hears Tim’s spluttering and looks up in the middle of scooping cookie dough into round balls.  He doesn’t quite freeze, but every line of his body goes tense.  For a long, stretching moment, all three of them stare at each other.

 

Then Jason pointedly looks away, turning back to the cookies.  His shoulders are still taut, but Tim is distracted by Batman swooping in, gauntleted arms reached out to catch Tim’s shoulders.

 

“Tim,” comes the voice, not quite the growl, not quite Bruce’s normal tone, “Are you hurt?”

 

Well, Tim has no doubt he’ll have an impressive array of bruises tomorrow morning, but he shakes his head.  “Jason rescued me,” he says quietly—and the enormity of that hits him.

 

Hood got him away from the traffickers, took him to the Cave, wrapped him in blankets, and made him tea and cookies. Tim wouldn’t have believed anyone who told him that this was going to happen, and he can understand the disbelief radiating out from Batman.

 

Jason still doesn’t look up, glaring at the cookies as he says casually, “Tim thinks you’re going to fire him.”

 

Tim stills.  The hands on his shoulders tighten.  Okay, so maybe Jason is still an asshole.

 

“Tim,” and this time it’s Bruce’s soft tone. “Why would you think that?”

 

Tim swallows.  He doesn’t glare at Jason, because there’s no point to it.  He stares at his tea and lets the warmth seep through his fingers.  “I went out on patrol,” he says quietly, “And I got captured.  I—I’m sorry, I know I’m—I’m not—I’m trying to do better, Bruce, I am—” it’s just not good enough, it’s never been good enough, and Tim wasn’t good enough for his parents and he’s certainly not good enough for Bruce Wayne.

 

The warm grip turns into a hug, and Tim is sobbing into the armor.  “Oh, sweetheart,” Bruce says softly. “You’re doing great.  I’m not going to send you away.  You’re my son.”

 

“But I—but Robin—I didn’t—”

 

“Tim, you will be my son regardless of Robin,” Bruce says—he draws slightly away, and Tim is met with warm blue eyes.  “Dick doesn’t need to be Robin to be my son.  Jason doesn’t need to be Robin to be my son.”  The parchment paper crinkles, accompanied by a low, choked sound.  “I love you, no matter what.”

 

Tim is—Bruce is saying—but he can’t—is Bruce really saying— “No matter what?” Tim asks shakily.

 

“No matter what,” Bruce vows, and Tim presses forward for another hug.

 

“No matter what,” Jason says, his tone cold and—and angry—and desperately hopeful all at once.

 

“No matter what, Jay,” Bruce repeats.  Tim raises his head enough to see that Bruce has extended a hand to Jason in wordless invitation.

 

Jason gives Tim a glance and clearly hesitates, so Tim wriggles until he can extend a hand too.  Jason takes a deep breath and lets it out slowly before he rounds the counter.

 

Jason smells like gunpowder.

 

But he also smells like cinnamon and honey-lemon.  Like home.

 

 

Jason cleans the mixing bowl and the mixer, trying to ignore the weight of the stare on his back as Dick munches through the leftover cookies.  Bruce went to put Tim to bed, so Dick is clearly on babysitting duty.  Watching Jason to make sure he isn’t up to something.

 

“Jason doesn’t need to be Robin to be my son.”

 

He doesn’t mean that.  He—he can’t mean that.

 

“So,” Dick says, and Jason tenses.  “You rescued Tim?”  The tone is polite.  Perfectly disguising the skepticism that’s definitely lurking underneath.

 

Understandable skepticism.  The last time Jason and Tim were in the same place, Jason left the kid with several broken bones.

 

“Yeah,” Jason replies hoarsely.  He waits for the rest of the interrogation, but there’s nothing but silence.

 

“These are good cookies,” Dick says after another lull, and Jason pauses drying to look at him.  There’s only one cookie left and Dick is eyeing it like he isn’t sure whether to be polite and save it for someone else, or to just scarf it down.

 

“Thanks,” Jason says, and turns back to the sink.  He can feel Dick’s stare as an itch between his shoulder blades, and, eventually, he can’t stand it.

 

“I had to pretend to buy him,” Jason says.

 

“I’m sorry?” Dick asks.

 

Jason swallows, and turns back around.  He forces himself to meet Dick Grayson’s assessing gaze, blue eyes intense and searching.  “I had to pretend to buy him,” Jason repeats. “From the traffickers.”

 

Dick doesn’t say anything.  Just waits, patient.

 

“I said,” Jason swallows, because he doesn’t even remember exactly what he said, but he remembers how it felt, how every word tasted like bile.  “I said some—some horrible things.  About what—what I was going to do to him.”

 

Dick is still calm.  Like this is four years ago, like Jason is still Robin and confessing to his older, wiser, more experienced brother.

 

But this isn’t four years ago, and Dick hasn’t been through what Jason’s been through.

 

“I pistol whipped him,” Jason says flatly. “And then I shoved the gun into his mouth.”

 

That causes blue eyes to narrow as Dick goes very, very still.

 

Jason turns away because—because he can’t—he doesn’t—he can still see Tim swallowing past the gun, skin pale in terror, and he doesn’t realize his fingers are trembling until he clutches the counter.

 

“It was the quickest way out of there,” Jason says, and he’s aware that it sounds like an excuse, but it was, it was the first thing that Jason thought of that could get them out without any trouble and now he’s wondering how many other ways were there, how many ways he could’ve talked his way out without insinuating that he was—that he was going to rape the kid—his little brother.

 

“Okay,” Dick says, and Jason doesn’t understand.

 

He can’t turn around, he can’t face Dick, all he can do is croak out a hoarse, “What?”

 

“Okay,” Dick repeats, “If you say it was the quickest way out, I believe you.”

 

Jason’s fingers keep trembling, because he can’t—because Dick wasn’t there—he didn’t have to listen to the jeers and lewd suggestions and terrifying threats aimed at the small, huddled form kneeling on the ground—because he didn’t have to look at an expression not completely covered by the mask and know that he sold his performance so well that everyone had bought it—he didn’t have to listen to them laugh as he kept his attention focused on the gun, on keeping his finger far, far away from the trigger even though he triple-checked that the safety was on—

 

“He—he thought—” Jason is distantly aware that he’s breathing too fast, arms shaking under the strain of keeping him upright— “I didn’t—he was—he was terrified—”

 

Jason is dimly aware of the sharp, shooting pains in his knees.  He blinks, and he’s staring at the drawers, hands clutching the counter above his head.

 

“Jason,” Dick says, closer now, and all Jason can do is press his face against the wood.

 

“He thought I was going to hurt him,” Jason says, hollow and raw.

 

“Oh, Little Wing,” Dick sighs, and Jason doesn’t fight the grip that tugs him away from the drawers, doesn’t fight the arms around his shoulder or the fingers in his hair.  He buries his face in his older brother’s shirt and lets the sobs claw their way out.

 

“Sometimes,” Dick says softly. “We have to act in a certain way or say certain things in the middle of a dangerous situation.  When doing the wrong thing means someone gets hurt, or worse.”

 

“I could’ve killed them,” Jason says hoarsely.  Dick’s fingers don’t stutter in their strokes.  “I could’ve killed everyone in that warehouse and walked out without saying a word to Robin.”

 

Dick hums.  “Why didn’t you?”

 

“They—they’re holding a group of children somewhere and I don’t—I need more time to find out and—”

 

“And if you killed them, they would’ve gone to ground,” Dick finishes. “You made a choice from the options available to you, Jaybird, and that’s all we can do.”  The fingers card gently through his hair.  “This is why we have reports and debriefs.  So when the situation is over, we can take a breath and explain ourselves.  Did you tell Tim why you did what you did?”

 

Jason nods against Dick’s shoulder.

 

“Good,” Dick says softly, “Next, I suggest you ask him if he’s okay with you doing it again, if needed, or if he prefers you chose a different option.”  Jason shudders at the thought of doing that again—he’ll kill anyone who puts him in that situation again, and he’ll make it slow.

 

“Sometimes you have to make the best of a set of bad choices,” Dick hums, and there’s a soft press against his forehead. “As long as everyone comes home, Jaybird.”

 

As long as everyone comes home.
